a.xlink:title: Ideally yes; mail clients are more secure than webmail and more convenient for both parties.
a.text: Are you using a proper PGP

a.xlink:title: The different addresses help Justin filter and reduce impact on others if one address is attacked, but there is no difference as far as spam scoring. The rasterized script font is to mitigate OCR-capable bot-executed address harvesting (to some extent).
The hushmail address us useable until Dec.31, 2018. The script font in this node is to mitigate OCR-capable bot-executed address harvesting (to some extent).

All gombos.info accounts are checked daily. The other two require Justin to do a manual web login. Protonmail have daily notifications, so Justin's response time is ~2 days. Tutanota does not, it could take ~2-3 weeks before a msg is spotted.
a.text: Note: expect a slow response time

a.xlink:title: The quickest one-off msg approach is to use keybase, but you won't have a readable saved copy of what you sent.
a.text: Note: the green path through this diagram
indicates the most convenient for regular
at the cost of higher initial setup effort.

a.xlink:title: Clicking this node goes to a wiki showing a table of MUAs with columns indicating S/MIME and PGP support
PGP key generation is a simple process.
S/MIME key generation is a little more tedious, although it's easy to send your public key.
a.text: a key pair, simply signing your
supply your public key to Justin.

a.xlink:title: hopefully yes
a.text: sent from a mail client or web-based

a.xlink:title: Sharing? yikes!
a.text: *or feeding his address to an information

a.xlink:title: These webmail services are relatively safe compared to other webmail services, but still 2nd to using a proper mail client
a.text: a hushmail, protonmail, or tutanota account?

a.xlink:title: If you'll need a reply, then Justin will need your key so he can reply securely.
If yes, you won't like the next node.

This is quite simple, and you can use your usual mail client or webmail service without any changes. If you want a reply, Justin will likely respond with a PDF that can be opened using whatever password you supply. Limitation: there is no way to send Justin a file attachment using this keybase mechanism.
a.text: Click here, or go to keybase.io/encrypt#alchemistanaut,
write your message, click 'encrypt', copy-paste the resulting
text into a normal msg. (if you need a reply, include a
passphrase of your choosing in the msg and remember it)

a.xlink:title: You might want to find a different path through the graph.
find a different path
Secure e-mail can be complicated, but Justin will support you.

Clicking will bring you to the github issues page, where you can describe your issue. Note that you'll need a github account to create an issue, and your entry will be publicly viewable. Alternatively, you can e-mail support questions to the address herein, in the clear if needed.
You'll need to have Justin's key before sending him a message. Once you have it, it's good until it expires (few years generally).
a.text: for the first time, or has his key expired?

a.xlink:title: You can instantly get Justin's key from the PDF container. Or you can e-mail him and wait. Whatever you find more convenient.
(using S/MIME or PGP)

If you don't know the address associated to the key, it will generally be the address from which Justin sent you the key. If you took the key from the PDF file, then it's evident from that file. PGP users: if you imported Justin's key from a PGP key server, then you should look at the table of addresses and select the best one. But note that you may have to configure your mail client to map key to address because Justin's published PGP keys have a deliberately unusable address.
You may have done this when first configuring your mail client, although it's not often part of the installation wizards (you most likely would have had to initiate the process).
a.text: Generate a key pair for yourself if you
have not already done so and ensure
the public key is accessible to Justin.

a.xlink:title: Clicking this will open a PDF container holding keys to choose from. Warning: if using an old browser, you may have to download the PDF and view in an external viewer.

Be sure to tell Justin whether you need a PGP key or an S/MIME certificate, or tell him your mail client. E-mailing is probably easier than the self-service PDF option, but obviously it's not instant.
a.text: Ask Justin for a key at:

a.xlink:title: Keep calm, carry on..
a.text: Do you need to e-mail Justin?

a.xlink:title: Exceptionally, if it's a key-signing party then simply follow the path of a normal e-mail.
a.text: addresses for these types of use cases.
Send him a normal e-mail first
(if you are sharing his address with
a human, share this diagram instead)
